title: William John Bowser
text:
William John Bowser (<a href="Rexton%2C%20New%20Brunswick">Rexton, New Brunswick</a> December 3, 1867 – October 25, 1933 <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a>) was a politician in <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, Canada. He served as the 17th <a href="premier%20of%20British%20Columbia">premier of British Columbia</a> from 1915 to 1916.
The son of William Bowser and Margaret Gordon, Bowser was educated at <a href="Mount%20Allison%20University">Mount Allison University</a> and <a href="Dalhousie%20University">Dalhousie University</a>. He moved to <a href="Vancouver">Vancouver</a> to practice law in 1891, and was first elected to the provincial <a href="legislature">legislature</a> in the <a href="1903%20British%20Columbia%20general%20election">1903 election</a> as a <a href="British%20Columbia%20Conservative%20Party">Conservative</a>. Bowser served as <a href="Attorney-General">Attorney-General</a> in the <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">cabinet</a> of Sir <a href="Richard%20McBride">Richard McBride</a> from 1907 until 1915. As Attorney-General, Bowser forced the Squamish First Nation, then the False Creek Indian Band, off Kitsilano Indian Reserve no.6.
In 1915, he succeeded McBride as <a href="Premier">Premier</a>.
The Conservative party was deeply divided and unpopular and the change in leadership did not improve matters. Accusations of corruption and "<a href="Political%20machine">machine politics</a>" were rife. The Conservatives also neglected to address popular demands for <a href="women%27s%20suffrage">women's suffrage</a> and <a href="prohibition">prohibition</a>. Bowser's government was defeated in the <a href="1916%20British%20Columbia%20general%20election">1916 election</a>, losing to Liberal leader Harlan Carey Brewster, who two years later was succeeded by the more memorable <a href="John%20Oliver%20%28British%20Columbia%20politician%29">John Oliver</a>. Bowser continued as <a href="Leader%20of%20the%20Opposition%20%28British%20Columbia%29">leader of the opposition</a> until he lost his seat in the <a href="1924%20British%20Columbia%20general%20election">1924 election</a>.
He returned to politics in the <a href="1933%20British%20Columbia%20general%20election">1933 election</a> to lead the <a href="Non-Partisan%20Independent%20Group">Non-Partisan Independent Group</a> of candidates, but died during the election campaign.
A river, a lake and the small community of <a href="Bowser%2C%20British%20Columbia">Bowser</a> on Vancouver Island, between Parksville and the Comox Valley, are named for Bowser.
